content: Limits have a number of properties that you can use to your advantage:

contents.content: $ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} k = k$, for any constant $k$
$ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} [ f(x) \ \pm \ h(x) ] = \ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} f(x) \ \pm \ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} h(x)$
$ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} [ kf(x)] = k [ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} f(x) ]$, for any constant $k$
$ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} [ f(x)g(x)] = [  ^{\lim}_{x \to a} f(x) ][  ^{\lim}_{x \to a} g(x) ]$
$ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \frac{ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} f(x)}{ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} g(x)}$, as long as $ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} g(x) \ne 0$
$ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} [ f(x)]^{n} = [ ^{\lim}_{x \to a} f(x)]^{n}$, for any rational number $n$

Take a look at the following graph of the function $ f(x) = \frac {1} {x} $
As you know, $ f(x) = \frac {1} {x} $ has an asymptote at $ x = 0 $, meaning the function is not defined there.
The limit for this function at $ x = 0 $ is not defined. Let's take a look at the left and right limits:
As $ x \to 0 $ from the left, it nears negative infinity ($-\infty$). so, $ ^{\lim}_{x \to 0^{-}} (\frac {1} {x}) = -\infty$
As $ x \to 0 $ from the right, it nears positive infinity ($+\infty$). so, $ ^{\lim}_{x \to 0^{+}} (\frac {1} {x}) = +\infty$
Let's also take a look at the limit of this function as $ x \to \pm \infty $:
As $ x \to - \infty $, $ f(x) \to 0 $ from the bottom
As $ x \to + \infty $, $ f(x) \to 0 $ from the top

Since both $+\infty$ and $-\infty$ are not real numbers, the left and right limits of $f(x)$ are not defined, which also makes the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approach $0$ undefined as well. However, this is useful for graphing the function near these asymptotes, since we can determine how they behave as $x$ gets closer to them. The same applies for horizontal asymptotes as well.
When solving an infinite limit for certain functions, you may end up with an indeterminate $ \pm \frac {\infty} {\infty} $ answer.
Using current methods, it is not possible to solve this limit.
A handy trick to solving these limits is to divide the numerator and denominator by $x$ of the highest power.
